epidemiology.timing: Usually develops within 2 years of DVT; assess at 3-6 months

pathophysiology.consequence: Ambulatory venous hypertension - pressure fails to drop with walking

villalta_scale.description: Validated scoring system for PTS diagnosis and severity

signs.items: Edema, skin induration, hyperpigmentation, venous ectasia, redness, pain on calf compression

presentation: Leg pain (aching, heaviness, tiredness) worse with standing
diagnosis: Villalta score ≥5 (at least 3-6 months after DVT)
Duplex ultrasound for reflux and obstruction assessment

iliac_stenting.indication: Iliofemoral obstruction with Villalta ≥10 or ulcer

prevention.anticoagulation: Adequate intensity and duration is most important
prevention.compression_stockings: SOX trial showed NO prevention benefit
prevention.thrombolysis: May reduce PTS in iliofemoral DVT (CaVenT, ATTRACT trials)

definition.@value: A chronic complication of deep venous thrombosis characterized by persistent symptoms and signs of venous hypertension due to valve destruction, persistent obstruction, or both, diagnosed by Villalta score ≥5.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Understand pathophysiology of PTS (valve damage + obstruction)
Apply Villalta scale for diagnosis and severity grading
Identify risk factors for PTS development
clinical_pearls: PTS develops in 20-50% of proximal DVT patients; iliofemoral DVT = HIGHEST risk
Villalta score ≥5 = PTS diagnosis; ≥15 or ulcer = severe PTS
SOX trial: compression stockings do NOT prevent PTS (use for symptom management only)
Assess at least 3 months after DVT to diagnose PTS (allow acute changes to resolve)
Iliac stenting is highly effective for obstructive component

medicalCode.description: Postthrombotic syndrome without ulcer of right lower extremity
Postthrombotic syndrome with ulcer of right lower extremity
